Award.AwardTitle: DYNAMICAL MODELS FOR SUPERDIFFUSION AND SUPERCONDUCTIVITY
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal is devoted to mathematical models of statistical mechanics. Some of the most intriguing issues in modern research are the non-classical phenomena of superdiffusion and superconductivity and the newly discovered doubling effect for the second moment (representing the superdiffusion coefficient). The PI will investigate these phenomena by employing various chaotic dynamical systems -- periodic Lorentz gases, the Galton board, Bunimovich stadia, diamonds with cusps, etc. He will also study the classical gas of hard balls whose ergodicity remains to be proved in full generality. The proposal also includes multiparticle gases with a common thermostat and the fluid dynamics governed by Navier-Stokes equations and quasi-geostrophic equations.

The proposal has a potentially broader impact on physics and other sciences. All its problems come from physics and the proposed research activities will have direct relevance to statistical mechanics, hydrodynamics, studies of electricity and superconductivity. The PI closely collaborates with physicists, other scientists, statisticians, and engineers. The PI publishes books and survey articles, maintains a web page with all his publications (including numerical data from computer experiments and the code), and uploads computer programs to MATLAB exchange public forums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to investigate statistical properties of chaotic dynamical systems modeling physical processes, with particular emphasis on the topological study of superdiffusive orbits of certain three- and four-dimensional semi-dispersive billiards.

Under my guidance, jointly with my PhD student Caleb C. Moxley we proved stunning lower and upper bounds for the radial size of the homotopical rotation set of several 3D cylindric billiard flows. The methods developed there enabled us to also obtain lower and upper bounds for the topological entropy of these flows. The results are being published in the paper "Homotopical Complexity of a 3D Billiard Flow" (accepted for publication in Contemporary Mathematics, 2016) and in the upcoming paper "On the Homotopical Rotation Sets of Certain 3D Billiard Flows".

I gave the following talks at major conferences on dynamical systems:

Invited participant of the "Fourth Abel Conference: A Celebration of Yakov G. Sinai" held at the Institute for Mathematics and Applications of the University of Minnesota, October 31 - November 2, 2014. Also, in connection with the above, I am an invited author of the third volume of the Springer book series on the Abel Prize laureates, devoted to the mathematical achievements of Yakov G. Sinai.


Invited talk "Wojtkowski's Falling Balls Revisited" at the AMS Special Session on Ergodic Theory and Dynamical Systems, San Antonio, TX, January 10, 2015 (Organized as part of the AMS-MAA 2015 Joint Mathematics Meetings.)

Invited talk "On homotopical rotation numbers" at the AMS Special Session on Topology and Topological Methods in Dynamical Systems, Huntsville, AL, March 28, 2015

Invited talk at the Geometry, Dynamics and Topology Day organized by the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science of Eastern Illinois University, Charleston, IL, April 25, 2015

Invited plenary talk at the Dynamical Systems, Ergodic Theory, and Probability conference dedicated to the memory of Nikolai  Chernov, University of Alabama at Birmingham, May 18-20, 2015

“Homotopical Complexity of Certain 3D Cylindric Billiards”. Talk at the Special Session on Fractal Geometry and Dynamical Systems  as part of the AMS Southeastern Sectional Meeting, Memphis, TN, October 2015

“Non-commutative rotation ectors for toroidal billiards”. Short talk at the 114th STATISTICAL MECHANICS CONFERENCE held at Rutgers University, December 13-15, 2015.

"Toward Wojtkowski's Falling Ball Conjecture". Talk in the Special Session "Topology and Dynamical Systems" at the AMS Spring 2016 Southeastern Sectional Meeting, Athens, Georgia.

"Homotopical Complexity of Two Billiard Models". Talk at the Dynamical Systems Seminar of Budapest University of Technology and Economics, May 13, 2016.

"Doma Szasz and the Boltzmann-Sinai Hypothesis" Plenary talk at the "Hyperbolic Dynamics and Statistical Physics" conference dedicated to the 75th birthday of Domokos Szász, May 17-21, 2016, Vienna, Austria.
